<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two one-dimensional copper(II) coordination polymers constructed from 2-hydroxypyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hhpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis and variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements, etc. Despite the different deprotonated forms of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, hydroxy-oxo tautomerism optimizes the coordination preferences of the ligands, presenting unique coordination polymers containing similar chain structures with different charge states. Moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between adjacent Cu (II) ions are observed in two compounds.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two one-dimensional copper(II) coordination polymers constructed from 2-hydroxypyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylic acid (H3hpdc), [Cu2(Hhpdc)2(NH3)2]⋅2NH3⋅H2O (1) and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)][Cu2(hpdc)2(NH3)2]⋅2H2O (2), have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis and variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements, etc. Despite the different deprotonated forms of H3hpdc in 1 and 2, hydroxy-oxo tautomerism optimizes the coordination preferences of the ligands, presenting unique coordination polymers containing similar chain structures with different charge states. Moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between adjacent Cu (II) ions are observed in two compounds.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

By governing the coordination preferences of 2-hydroxypyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylic acid ligand based on hydroxy-oxo tautomerism, unique examples of one-dimensional coordination polymers with the same binding mode but different charge states have been obtained.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► Cu (II) coordination polymers. ► Hydroxy-oxo tautomerism. ► Common chain linkage mode with different charge states. ► Magnetic properties.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Crystal engineering (CE) of coordination polymers has become an important current topic in the field of solid state materials . The infinite one-dimensional (1D) chains, being the simplest topology of coordination polymers, have been extensively investigated due to their anisotropic structures and ease of formation by self-assembly, which can favor the construction and modification of materials with specific magnetic, electrical and optical properties by tailoring the constituent molecules . Based on self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands with different shape and flexibility, various 1D coordination polymeric motifs such as linear, zigzag, helical etc., have been reported . It is also possible to manipulate the shape and packing of the coordination chains with the same metal atoms and organic ligands by changing the counterions, solvents or reaction temperatures . However, it remains a great challenge to regulate the charge states of 1D chain with same coordination skeleton because the close association between coordination modes and charge states of organic bridging ligands easily results in the formation of various structural motifs. To adjust the structure and properties of the coordination polymeric chains in a controllable manner, the intelligent design and judicious choice of ligand are very crucial .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► Cu (II) coordination polymers. ► Hydroxy-oxo tautomerism. ► Common chain linkage mode with different charge states. ► Magnetic properties.

Crystal engineering (CE) of coordination polymers has become an important current topic in the field of solid state materials . The infinite one-dimensional (1D) chains, being the simplest topology of coordination polymers, have been extensively investigated due to their anisotropic structures and ease of formation by self-assembly, which can favor the construction and modification of materials with specific magnetic, electrical and optical properties by tailoring the constituent molecules . Based on self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands with different shape and flexibility, various 1D coordination polymeric motifs such as linear, zigzag, helical etc., have been reported . It is also possible to manipulate the shape and packing of the coordination chains with the same metal atoms and organic ligands by changing the counterions, solvents or reaction temperatures . However, it remains a great challenge to regulate the charge states of 1D chain with same coordination skeleton because the close association between coordination modes and charge states of organic bridging ligands easily results in the formation of various structural motifs. To adjust the structure and properties of the coordination polymeric chains in a controllable manner, the intelligent design and judicious choice of ligand are very crucial .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">2-Hydroxypyrimidine-4, 6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc) is an appropriate candidate for manipulating the structure of coordination polymers due to the following advantages: (a) the carboxylate groups may cooperate with the pyrimidine nitrogen to adopt a typical tetradentate bischelate bridging mode, having a tendency to assemble into 1D chain structures by the link of metal ions. (b) The presence of hydroxyl group not only provides the potential capability for adjusting the coordination mode and charge state of the ligand by deprotonation (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), but also may optimize the binding site by hydroxy-oxo tautomerism . (c) The potential coupling pathway via pyrimidine ring is convenient for analyzing magneto-structural correlations. By using this ligand, we have successfully obtained a series of 1D coordination polymers with intriguing magnetic behaviors and observed thermally-triggered reversible transformation between parallel staggered and plywood-like stacking of polymer chains , in which it was found that all hydroxyl groups participate in the coordination to metal centers. Herein, we report an interesting example of tuning charge state of 1D polymeric chains based on hydroxy-oxo tautomerism of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc ligand. The neutral and charged 1D Cu(II) coordination polymers with the same binding mode, of formulate [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hhpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been obtained by the self-assembly of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc ligand and the Cu(II) ion in the presence of ammonia . The magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal that the magnetic interactions are dominated by the antiferromagnetic coupling between copper ions in these two compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 2-Hydroxypyrimidine-4, 6-dicarboxylic acid (H3hpdc) is an appropriate candidate for manipulating the structure of coordination polymers due to the following advantages: (a) the carboxylate groups may cooperate with the pyrimidine nitrogen to adopt a typical tetradentate bischelate bridging mode, having a tendency to assemble into 1D chain structures by the link of metal ions. (b) The presence of hydroxyl group not only provides the potential capability for adjusting the coordination mode and charge state of the ligand by deprotonation ( ), but also may optimize the binding site by hydroxy-oxo tautomerism . (c) The potential coupling pathway via pyrimidine ring is convenient for analyzing magneto-structural correlations. By using this ligand, we have successfully obtained a series of 1D coordination polymers with intriguing magnetic behaviors and observed thermally-triggered reversible transformation between parallel staggered and plywood-like stacking of polymer chains , in which it was found that all hydroxyl groups participate in the coordination to metal centers. Herein, we report an interesting example of tuning charge state of 1D polymeric chains based on hydroxy-oxo tautomerism of the H3hpdc ligand. The neutral and charged 1D Cu(II) coordination polymers with the same binding mode, of formulate [Cu2(Hhpdc)2(NH3)2]⋅2NH3⋅H2O (1) and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)][Cu2(hpdc)2(NH3)2]⋅2H2O (2), have been obtained by the self-assembly of the H3hpdc ligand and the Cu(II) ion in the presence of ammonia . The magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal that the magnetic interactions are dominated by the antiferromagnetic coupling between copper ions in these two compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">X-ray analysis reveals that compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possess similar 1D coordination polymer chains (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>), in which the metal centers are sequentially bridged by pyrimidine-N and carboxylate-O atoms in bis-chelating mode . The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> comprises a crystallographically unique copper atom, one Hhpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, one coordinated and one lattice ammonia molecule, and half lattice water molecule occupying interchain position. The Cu(II) ion displays a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.62) , being coordinated with two NO donor sets coming from two asymmetrical Hhpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and one ammonia molecule. The N–Cu–O chelate bite angles are 80.58° and 80.10°, respectively. The dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings is 61.11°. Each Cu(II) ion is connected via <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>NCN<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph> bridge to give a 1D wedge-shaped polymer chain with the nearest Cu···Cu distance of 5.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The 1D linear chains stack in an antiparallel manner, which are held together by the hydrogen-bonding interactions among the lattice water and ammonia molecules, coordinated ammonia molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms to generate a 3D supramolecular framework (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: X-ray analysis reveals that compounds 1 and 2 possess similar 1D coordination polymer chains ( ), in which the metal centers are sequentially bridged by pyrimidine-N and carboxylate-O atoms in bis-chelating mode . The asymmetric unit of compound 1 comprises a crystallographically unique copper atom, one Hhpdc2- anion, one coordinated and one lattice ammonia molecule, and half lattice water molecule occupying interchain position. The Cu(II) ion displays a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (τ=0.62) , being coordinated with two NO donor sets coming from two asymmetrical Hhpdc2- ligands and one ammonia molecule. The N-Cu-O chelate bite angles are 80.58° and 80.10°, respectively. The dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings is 61.11°. Each Cu(II) ion is connected via NCN bridge to give a 1D wedge-shaped polymer chain with the nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 5.96Å. The 1D linear chains stack in an antiparallel manner, which are held together by the hydrogen-bonding interactions among the lattice water and ammonia molecules, coordinated ammonia molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms to generate a 3D supramolecular framework (d).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Despite a similar chain linkage mode that is observed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the symmetry character in crystal lattices of the two compounds is different. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains one and a half crystallographically unique Cu atoms, one hpdc<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anion, three coordinated ammonia molecules occupying four different lattice sites, a half of coordinated water molecule, and two independent half-occupied lattice water molecules. The Cu1 atom shows similar coordination environment and linkage to those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but exhibits a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.28), accompanied by a slight change in the N–Cu–O chelate bite angles (78.32° and 81.84°), and the dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings (72.87°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cu2 atom is located in a nearly perfect square-pyramidal geometry (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.09), coordinated by four ammonia molecules in equatorial positions and one water molecule with longer bond directed toward the axial position (Fig. S1). The bridge modes of 1D polymer chain in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are identical to that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> but the nearest Cu···Cu distance slightly extends to 6.06<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Due to the existence of the cationic unit involving the Cu2 atom, [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, the 1D polymer chain built up by pentacoordinated Cu1 atom should be negatively charged in order to achieve charge balance within the whole crystal. In this case, it is considered that the hydrogen atom on the hydroxyl group of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc molecule might be further removed to contribute an additional negative charge to chain-like polymer during the molecular assembly. Different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in which the hydroxyl group associates with three carboxylate oxygen atoms of adjacent Hhpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands through one lattice ammonia molecule based on hydrogen bonding interactions (the N···O distances: 2.79–2.88<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), no appropriate hydrogen bonding interaction (the N···O or O···O distances: <<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) with the hydroxyl oxygen atom can be observed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Furthermore, the IR spectrum (Fig. S2) of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits an additional peak at about 1684<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which is characteristic for the exocyclic carbonyl bond (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) stretching vibration . Therefore, a carbonyl (oxo) tautomeric form is considered to exist predominantly in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after deprotonation of the hydroxyl group. This change in preference to the oxo tautomer should be beneficial to avoid this group to coordinate with the metal ion as the negative charge is delocalized over the nitrogen atom , and provide a precondition for forming similar topological linkage with different charge states.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Despite a similar chain linkage mode that is observed in 2, the symmetry character in crystal lattices of the two compounds is different. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one and a half crystallographically unique Cu atoms, one hpdc3- anion, three coordinated ammonia molecules occupying four different lattice sites, a half of coordinated water molecule, and two independent half-occupied lattice water molecules. The Cu1 atom shows similar coordination environment and linkage to those in 1, but exhibits a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.28), accompanied by a slight change in the N-Cu-O chelate bite angles (78.32° and 81.84°), and the dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings (72.87°) ( ). The Cu2 atom is located in a nearly perfect square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.09), coordinated by four ammonia molecules in equatorial positions and one water molecule with longer bond directed toward the axial position (Fig. S1). The bridge modes of 1D polymer chain in 2 are identical to that in 1 but the nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance slightly extends to 6.06Å. Due to the existence of the cationic unit involving the Cu2 atom, [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+, the 1D polymer chain built up by pentacoordinated Cu1 atom should be negatively charged in order to achieve charge balance within the whole crystal. In this case, it is considered that the hydrogen atom on the hydroxyl group of the H3hpdc molecule might be further removed to contribute an additional negative charge to chain-like polymer during the molecular assembly. Different from 1, in which the hydroxyl group associates with three carboxylate oxygen atoms of adjacent Hhpdc2- ligands through one lattice ammonia molecule based on hydrogen bonding interactions (the N⋅⋅⋅O distances: 2.79-2.88Å), no appropriate hydrogen bonding interaction (the N⋅⋅⋅O or O⋅⋅⋅O distances: <3.0Å) with the hydroxyl oxygen atom can be observed in 2. Furthermore, the IR spectrum (Fig. S2) of 2 exhibits an additional peak at about 1684cm-1, which is characteristic for the exocyclic carbonyl bond (CO) stretching vibration . Therefore, a carbonyl (oxo) tautomeric form is considered to exist predominantly in 2 after deprotonation of the hydroxyl group. This change in preference to the oxo tautomer should be beneficial to avoid this group to coordinate with the metal ion as the negative charge is delocalized over the nitrogen atom , and provide a precondition for forming similar topological linkage with different charge states.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">1D coordination polymers are ubiquitous and have been widely studied in the field of coordination chemistry. By manipulating the counterions, solvent conditions or reaction temperatures, the coordination chains with different shapes or packing modes have been obtained . However, it is a hard challenge to get common 1D chain structures with different charge states because the charge states of organic ligands greatly affect their coordination modes. The achievement in obtaining charge isomers of 1D coordination polymer should be owed to the ability of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc ligand to control charge distribution by hydroxy-oxo tautomerism for optimizing its coordination preference. Furthermore, high tendency of the pyrimidine-dicarboxylate to adopt chelating coordination through the endocyclic nitrogen atom and the carboxylate oxygen atom may also play a role in facilitating the formation of common topological structures. More remarkably, the presence of free [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit has only a slight influence on the packing arrangement of the 1D chains, which is different from the usual observations that the shapes and packing states of chains easily undergo variation in response to different guest molecules or counterions . The chains are stacked in the same way as in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with the [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and lattice water molecules located between them, showing a small increase of the interchain distances from 5.94 to 6.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to 6.63 and 7.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (based on the linear Cu(II) backbone). The hydrogen bonds among the [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cationic units, lattice water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms hold the 1D chains into 3D supramolecular framework (e).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 1D coordination polymers are ubiquitous and have been widely studied in the field of coordination chemistry. By manipulating the counterions, solvent conditions or reaction temperatures, the coordination chains with different shapes or packing modes have been obtained . However, it is a hard challenge to get common 1D chain structures with different charge states because the charge states of organic ligands greatly affect their coordination modes. The achievement in obtaining charge isomers of 1D coordination polymer should be owed to the ability of the H3hpdc ligand to control charge distribution by hydroxy-oxo tautomerism for optimizing its coordination preference. Furthermore, high tendency of the pyrimidine-dicarboxylate to adopt chelating coordination through the endocyclic nitrogen atom and the carboxylate oxygen atom may also play a role in facilitating the formation of common topological structures. More remarkably, the presence of free [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ unit has only a slight influence on the packing arrangement of the 1D chains, which is different from the usual observations that the shapes and packing states of chains easily undergo variation in response to different guest molecules or counterions . The chains are stacked in the same way as in 1, with the [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ cations and lattice water molecules located between them, showing a small increase of the interchain distances from 5.94 to 6.01Å in 1 to 6.63 and 7.53Å in 2 (based on the linear Cu(II) backbone). The hydrogen bonds among the [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ cationic units, lattice water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms hold the 1D chains into 3D supramolecular framework (e).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement (Fig. S3) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a first weight loss of about 3.12% in the range of 85–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is in accordance with the removal of one water molecule (3.12%). The TG trace of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals that the first weight loss (10.19%) in the temperature range of 85–148<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds well to the release of three water molecules and one ammonia molecule (10.02%). The weight loss (7.47%) at the second step (148–290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) can be ascribed to the loss of three ammonia molecules. Upon further heating, the elimination of residual ammonia molecules and decomposition of the carboxylate ligands occur in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement (Fig. S3) of 1 shows a first weight loss of about 3.12% in the range of 85-240°C, which is in accordance with the removal of one water molecule (3.12%). The TG trace of 2 reveals that the first weight loss (10.19%) in the temperature range of 85-148°C corresponds well to the release of three water molecules and one ammonia molecule (10.02%). The weight loss (7.47%) at the second step (148-290°C) can be ascribed to the loss of three ammonia molecules. Upon further heating, the elimination of residual ammonia molecules and decomposition of the carboxylate ligands occur in 1 and 2.

elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility of 1 with an applied field of 2kOe reveals that the χ  m  T value at 300K is 0.82cm3 Kmol-1 ( ), which is slightly larger than the calculated value of 0.75cm3 Kmol-1 for a non-coupled two-spin (S  1  = S  2  =1/2, g =2.0) system. As the temperature is lowered, the χ  m  T value decreases quickly and approaches zero at 2.0K. The fit of the experimental data to the Curie-Weiss law above 70K gives a Curie constant C =1.05cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant θ =-82.62K. The negative large θ value suggests the presence of strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the Cu(II) ions. The temperature-dependence of the χ  m  T product of 2 was investigated in a magnetic field of 2kOe (). The observed χ  m  T value per Cu3 unit at 300K is 1.14cm3 Kmol-1, corresponding well to the expected spin-only value of 1.13cm3 Kmol-1 for three uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g =2. Upon further cooling, the χ  m  T value continuously decreases down to 0.08cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The Curie-Weiss fit to the magnetic susceptibility data above 40K gives a Curie constant of 1.31cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ =-40.77K, indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. Bearing in mind the structure of 1, the magnetic susceptibility data in the temperature range of 2-300K was fitted by Eq.  based on the modified Bonner and Fischer model  for 1D Heisenberg systems with J <0 with the Hamiltonian being H =-2J ∑  i  S  i  S  i +1   (1)    χ  m ( c h a i n )   = ( N  g 2   β 2  / k T ) ( 0.25 + 0.14995 x + 0.30094  x 2  ) / ( 1.0 + 1.9862 x + 0.68854  x 2  + 6.0626  x 3  )    where x =|J|/ kT, J is the exchange coupling constant between two nearest-neighbor spin doublets and other symbols have their usual meaning. The best-fitting parameters for compound 1 gave g =2.25, J =-28.38cm-1. Since compound 2 contained the [Cu2(hpdc)2(NH3)2]2- and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ units, the χ  m  was divided into χ  m(chain)  and χ  Cu :  (2)    χ  m =    χ  m   c h a i n   +    χ Cu     where     χ  C u   = N  g 1 2   β 2  / 4 k T .

elements.clean_text: The magnetic data were fitted by Eq.  in the temperature range of 25-300K, giving g =2.18, J =-28.06cm-1 when g  1  was fixed at 2.0. Such coupling constants are of the same magnitude as that found in the pyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylate-based 1D Cu(II) complexes, Cu(μ-pmdc)(H2O)2 (g =2.14, J =-32.7cm-1), suggesting moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions within the polymer chains. The deviation presumably relates to the coordination geometry change of the Cu(II) ion that may affect the magnetic orbital overlap .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In conclusion, two 1D Cu(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized based on 2-hydroxypyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylic acid ligand. The hydroxy-oxo tautomerism optimizes the coordination preferences of the ligand, presenting a unique example of tuning the charge state of one-dimensional coordination polymers with the same binding mode. Moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between adjacent Cu(II) ions are observed in two compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, two 1D Cu(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized based on 2-hydroxypyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylic acid ligand. The hydroxy-oxo tautomerism optimizes the coordination preferences of the ligand, presenting a unique example of tuning the charge state of one-dimensional coordination polymers with the same binding mode. Moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between adjacent Cu(II) ions are observed in two compounds.

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Despite a similar chain linkage mode that is observed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the symmetry character in crystal lattices of the two compounds is different. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains one and a half crystallographically unique Cu atoms, one hpdc<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anion, three coordinated ammonia molecules occupying four different lattice sites, a half of coordinated water molecule, and two independent half-occupied lattice water molecules. The Cu1 atom shows similar coordination environment and linkage to those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but exhibits a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.28), accompanied by a slight change in the N–Cu–O chelate bite angles (78.32° and 81.84°), and the dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings (72.87°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cu2 atom is located in a nearly perfect square-pyramidal geometry (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.09), coordinated by four ammonia molecules in equatorial positions and one water molecule with longer bond directed toward the axial position (Fig. S1). The bridge modes of 1D polymer chain in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are identical to that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> but the nearest Cu···Cu distance slightly extends to 6.06<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Due to the existence of the cationic unit involving the Cu2 atom, [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, the 1D polymer chain built up by pentacoordinated Cu1 atom should be negatively charged in order to achieve charge balance within the whole crystal. In this case, it is considered that the hydrogen atom on the hydroxyl group of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>hpdc molecule might be further removed to contribute an additional negative charge to chain-like polymer during the molecular assembly. Different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in which the hydroxyl group associates with three carboxylate oxygen atoms of adjacent Hhpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands through one lattice ammonia molecule based on hydrogen bonding interactions (the N···O distances: 2.79–2.88<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), no appropriate hydrogen bonding interaction (the N···O or O···O distances: <<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) with the hydroxyl oxygen atom can be observed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Furthermore, the IR spectrum (Fig. S2) of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits an additional peak at about 1684<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which is characteristic for the exocyclic carbonyl bond (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) stretching vibration . Therefore, a carbonyl (oxo) tautomeric form is considered to exist predominantly in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after deprotonation of the hydroxyl group. This change in preference to the oxo tautomer should be beneficial to avoid this group to coordinate with the metal ion as the negative charge is delocalized over the nitrogen atom , and provide a precondition for forming similar topological linkage with different charge states.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement (Fig. S3) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a first weight loss of about 3.12% in the range of 85–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is in accordance with the removal of one water molecule (3.12%). The TG trace of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals that the first weight loss (10.19%) in the temperature range of 85–148<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds well to the release of three water molecules and one ammonia molecule (10.02%). The weight loss (7.47%) at the second step (148–290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) can be ascribed to the loss of three ammonia molecules. Upon further heating, the elimination of residual ammonia molecules and decomposition of the carboxylate ligands occur in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Despite a similar chain linkage mode that is observed in 2, the symmetry character in crystal lattices of the two compounds is different. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one and a half crystallographically unique Cu atoms, one hpdc3- anion, three coordinated ammonia molecules occupying four different lattice sites, a half of coordinated water molecule, and two independent half-occupied lattice water molecules. The Cu1 atom shows similar coordination environment and linkage to those in 1, but exhibits a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.28), accompanied by a slight change in the N-Cu-O chelate bite angles (78.32° and 81.84°), and the dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings (72.87°) ( ). The Cu2 atom is located in a nearly perfect square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.09), coordinated by four ammonia molecules in equatorial positions and one water molecule with longer bond directed toward the axial position (Fig. S1). The bridge modes of 1D polymer chain in 2 are identical to that in 1 but the nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance slightly extends to 6.06Å. Due to the existence of the cationic unit involving the Cu2 atom, [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+, the 1D polymer chain built up by pentacoordinated Cu1 atom should be negatively charged in order to achieve charge balance within the whole crystal. In this case, it is considered that the hydrogen atom on the hydroxyl group of the H3hpdc molecule might be further removed to contribute an additional negative charge to chain-like polymer during the molecular assembly. Different from 1, in which the hydroxyl group associates with three carboxylate oxygen atoms of adjacent Hhpdc2- ligands through one lattice ammonia molecule based on hydrogen bonding interactions (the N⋅⋅⋅O distances: 2.79-2.88Å), no appropriate hydrogen bonding interaction (the N⋅⋅⋅O or O⋅⋅⋅O distances: <3.0Å) with the hydroxyl oxygen atom can be observed in 2. Furthermore, the IR spectrum (Fig. S2) of 2 exhibits an additional peak at about 1684cm-1, which is characteristic for the exocyclic carbonyl bond (CO) stretching vibration . Therefore, a carbonyl (oxo) tautomeric form is considered to exist predominantly in 2 after deprotonation of the hydroxyl group. This change in preference to the oxo tautomer should be beneficial to avoid this group to coordinate with the metal ion as the negative charge is delocalized over the nitrogen atom , and provide a precondition for forming similar topological linkage with different charge states.

Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement (Fig. S3) of 1 shows a first weight loss of about 3.12% in the range of 85-240°C, which is in accordance with the removal of one water molecule (3.12%). The TG trace of 2 reveals that the first weight loss (10.19%) in the temperature range of 85-148°C corresponds well to the release of three water molecules and one ammonia molecule (10.02%). The weight loss (7.47%) at the second step (148-290°C) can be ascribed to the loss of three ammonia molecules. Upon further heating, the elimination of residual ammonia molecules and decomposition of the carboxylate ligands occur in 1 and 2.

decomposition temperature.type: release of three water molecules and one ammonia molecule

cln_elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility of 1 with an applied field of 2kOe reveals that the χ  m  T value at 300K is 0.82cm3 Kmol-1 ( ), which is slightly larger than the calculated value of 0.75cm3 Kmol-1 for a non-coupled two-spin (S  1  = S  2  =1/2, g =2.0) system. As the temperature is lowered, the χ  m  T value decreases quickly and approaches zero at 2.0K. The fit of the experimental data to the Curie-Weiss law above 70K gives a Curie constant C =1.05cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant θ =-82.62K. The negative large θ value suggests the presence of strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the Cu(II) ions. The temperature-dependence of the χ  m  T product of 2 was investigated in a magnetic field of 2kOe (). The observed χ  m  T value per Cu3 unit at 300K is 1.14cm3 Kmol-1, corresponding well to the expected spin-only value of 1.13cm3 Kmol-1 for three uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g =2. Upon further cooling, the χ  m  T value continuously decreases down to 0.08cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The Curie-Weiss fit to the magnetic susceptibility data above 40K gives a Curie constant of 1.31cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ =-40.77K, indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. Bearing in mind the structure of 1, the magnetic susceptibility data in the temperature range of 2-300K was fitted by Eq.  based on the modified Bonner and Fischer model  for 1D Heisenberg systems with J <0 with the Hamiltonian being H =-2J ∑  i  S  i  S  i +1   (1)    χ  m ( c h a i n )   = ( N  g 2   β 2  / k T ) ( 0.25 + 0.14995 x + 0.30094  x 2  ) / ( 1.0 + 1.9862 x + 0.68854  x 2  + 6.0626  x 3  )    where x =|J|/ kT, J is the exchange coupling constant between two nearest-neighbor spin doublets and other symbols have their usual meaning. The best-fitting parameters for compound 1 gave g =2.25, J =-28.38cm-1. Since compound 2 contained the [Cu2(hpdc)2(NH3)2]2- and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ units, the χ  m  was divided into χ  m(chain)  and χ  Cu :  (2)    χ  m =    χ  m   c h a i n   +    χ Cu     where     χ  C u   = N  g 1 2   β 2  / 4 k T .

equation.parameters: x = |J|/kT, J is the exchange coupling constant between two nearest-neighbor spin doublets

cln_elements.clean_text:
The magnetic data were fitted by Eq.  in the temperature range of 25-300K, giving g =2.18, J =-28.06cm-1 when g  1  was fixed at 2.0. Such coupling constants are of the same magnitude as that found in the pyrimidine-4,6-dicarboxylate-based 1D Cu(II) complexes, Cu(μ-pmdc)(H2O)2 (g =2.14, J =-32.7cm-1), suggesting moderate antiferromagnetic coupling interactions within the polymer chains. The deviation presumably relates to the coordination geometry change of the Cu(II) ion that may affect the magnetic orbital overlap .

Crystallographic data for complex 1 (C12H18Cu2N8O11, Mr=577.42): monoclinic C2/c, a =17.448(13), b =11.950(7), c =11.898(9)Å, β =128.532(7)°, V =1940(2)Å3, T =294K, Z =4, D  c  =1.977gcm-3, μ =2.272mm-1, F (000)=1168, GOF =1.135, R 1 (I >2σ(I))=0.0383 and wR 2 (all data)=0.1095. For 2 (C12H26Cu3N10O13, Mr=709.05): Orthorhombic Pnma, a =12.116(6), b =15.047(7), c =13.262(6)Å, V =2418(2)Å3, T =294K, Z =4, Dc =1.948gcm-3, μ =2.699mm-1, F (000)=1436, GOF =1.095, R 1 (I >2σ(I))=0.0385 and wR 2 (all data)=0.1123. Data collections of 1 and 2 were carried out on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromator Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Absorption correction was performed using the multi-scan method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program package.

<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">(a) The common chain linkage mode in compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (b) View of 1D chain in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> down the polymer axis. (c) View of 1D chain in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> down the polymer axis. (d) The packing structure of chains in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (e) The packing structure of chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, in which the [Cu(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations are located. All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) The common chain linkage mode in compounds 1 and 2. (b) View of 1D chain in 1 down the polymer axis. (c) View of 1D chain in 2 down the polymer axis. (d) The packing structure of chains in 1. (e) The packing structure of chains in 2, in which the [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ cations are located. All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
